q: What is mouth cancer?
a: Mouth cancer, also known as oral cancer, refers to the growth of cancerous cells in any part of the mouth. It can occur on the lips, tongue, gums, roof of the mouth, or inside the cheeks. It is important to note the symptoms and causes of mouth cancer for early detection and treatment.

q: What are the symptoms of mouth cancer?
a: Symptoms of mouth cancer may include persistent mouth sores, pain or discomfort in the mouth, difficulty swallowing or chewing, a change in voice, unexplained bleeding, and numbness or tingling in the mouth or lips. It is important to consult a healthcare professional if you experience any of these symptoms.

q: What are the causes of mouth cancer?
a: The exact cause of mouth cancer is unknown, but certain factors can increase the risk. These include tobacco use (smoking or chewing), excessive alcohol consumption, persistent HPV infection, poor oral hygiene, a weakened immune system, and a family history of cancer.

q: What tests are conducted to diagnose mouth cancer?
a: To diagnose mouth cancer, a healthcare professional may conduct a physical examination of the mouth, throat, and neck. They may also perform a biopsy, imaging tests such as X-rays or CT scans, or use a special dye to identify abnormal cells.

q: What are the next steps after a mouth cancer diagnosis?
a: After a mouth cancer diagnosis, the next steps may involve further tests to determine the stage and spread of cancer. The healthcare team will discuss treatment options, which may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of these. It is important to follow the recommended treatment plan and seek support from healthcare professionals.

a: Treatment for mouth cancer depends on various factors such as the stage of cancer, its location, and the patient's overall health. The healthcare team will determine the most suitable treatment plan.
